summary: Topic 8.2 talks about two key components of ecosystems: energy and matter. This lesson will focus on ways energy transfers between organisms through food webs and tropic levels, and the ways matter and nutrients cycle through the environment, focusing on water, carbon, nitrogen, and phosphorus.

vocab.definition: The biological process by which organisms maintain a stable internal environment necessary for survival, even when external conditions change
The process by which an animal maintains a stable internal body temperature
Organisms that generate most of their own body heat, allowing them to maintain a stable internal temperature independent of their environment
An animal that is dependent on external sources of body heat
A state of suspended sexual and reproductive development in adult insects and other arthropods
The speed at which the body uses energy to maintain its basic functions, such as breathing, circulation, and cell growth
A natural area where living organisms (biotic factors) interact with each other and their non-living environment (abiotic factors) to form a self-sufficient system
All the living components within an ecosystem, such as plants, animals, fungi, and bacteria
The non-living, chemical, and physical components of an environment that shape an ecosystem and influence living organisms
Mass in a closed system cannot be created or destroyed during a chemical or physical change, only rearranged
Energy cannot be created or destroyed, only transformed from one form to another within an isolated system
The continuous movement and transformation of water on, above, and below the Earth's surface, driven by solar energy and gravity
Describes the continuous movement of carbon between the Earth's atmosphere, oceans, land, and living organisms
Describes how nitrogen moves between the atmosphere, soil, water, and living organisms through the processes of fixation, nitrification, ammonification, assimilation, and denitrification
Describes how phosphorus moves between rocks, soil, water, and living organisms through weathering, decomposition, and human activity
Organisms that produce their own food from inorganic substances in their environment
Describes organisms that can convert light energy into chemical energy through the process of photosynthesis
Describes the biological process of chemosynthesis, where organisms use chemical energy, rather than sunlight, to convert inorganic compounds into organic food
An organism that cannot produce its own food, instead taking nutrition from other sources of organic carbon, mainly matter from other organisms
The position an organism occupies in a food chain; describe how energy is transferred through an ecosystem as organisms consume one another
A natural system of interconnected food chains that illustrates the flow of energy through an ecosystem by showing which organisms are eaten by others
